realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Extend the pen tip and hold the barrel in your free hand. Keep the pen angled toward the sofa leg but outside its travel zone. With each thrust, tap the metal tip against different spots on your opposite palm, lightly dragging between taps, then lower the pen to rest.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Quick, light taps with the pen emulate a tiny impact signal without large resistance, slightly better, but the fundamental heavy-leg control problem still undermines lightsaber realism.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: spray bottle with white trigger nozzle and translucent blue liquid
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Stand the bottle on the floor, nozzle angled slightly toward the sofa leg yet 12 cm beyond its furthest point. Hold the neck with your free hand, press the ridged nozzle head against your palm, then drag the angled tip across your skin while the leg completes its thrust.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Ridged plastic gives low-force texture and avoids leg contact, acceptable for minimal resistance. The sofa-leg heft and limited movement freedom, however, still keep the simulation from feeling like a massless blade.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: red instant ramen noodle packet (Shin Ramyun)
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Lay the sealed packet flat on the floor 10 cm ahead of the sofa leg’s stopping point, uneven surface facing upward. While thrusting, press your free palm onto the packet, compress slightly, and sweep off the edge before the leg completes its motion.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: The air-filled, crinkly packet provides a soft, yielding feel with quick rebound—closer to a slime-like response yet still low resistance. No sofa-leg/substrate collision occurs, so the main flaw remains the heavy leg control, but the substrate feedback is comparatively appropriate.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the sponge green side up on the floor parallel to the sofa leg, nearest edge 8 cm beyond the leg’s reach. During each thrust, lower your free palm onto the sponge, rock the hand forward and backward, then lift away before the leg stops.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: The sponge offers a moist, compliant texture reminiscent of slicing through viscous material yet exerts minimal resistance. Despite the sofa-leg mass problem, the tactile cue is one of the better fits for the slime-cutting illusion.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: pair of scissors with orange handles and black blades
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Keep the blades closed and hold the handles in your free hand. Angle the closed tip toward—but not touching—the sofa leg’s path. With each thrust, tap the closed tip onto your palm at several points, then pull it back before the leg reaches full extension.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Metal scissor tips create sharp, localized pokes—too focused and forceful versus the desired low-resistance pass-through. Sofa-leg limitations continue.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: hand broom with wooden handle and black bristles
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Lay the broom on the floor with bristles pointing upward, handle parallel to the sofa leg, bristle field starting 10 cm beyond the leg’s stopping point. While thrusting, lower your free palm onto the bristle tips, sweep sideways, then lift away before the leg arrives.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Light bristle contact offers minimal resistance and a spreading sensation that could hint at cutting through matter. Still, the sofa-leg heft and absence of free wrist motion hinder the lightsaber illusion.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: dark gray/black swivel office chair with armrests
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Position the office chair beside the sofa so its mesh backrest faces the thrusting leg with a 15 cm air gap. As you thrust the leg, press the back of your free hand against the mesh, slide along the armrest’s hard edge, then withdraw before the leg draws even with the chair.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: The office chair is large; accidental collision risk undermines the ‘no resistance’ rule. Sliding along rigid armrest edges produces sustained contact, not the fleeting non-resistant slice required.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: green plush turtle shell cushion with white border
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Lay the cushion dome-up on the floor 8 cm beyond the sofa leg’s endpoint. During each thrust, rest your free palm on a raised segment, press downward to compress, slide across a stitched ridge, then lift before the leg reaches the cushion.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Soft plush compression with little resistance gives a gooey, yielding feel matching slime better than many substrates, while still avoiding leg contact. The heavy sofa leg remains the main break in realism.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: yellow snack packet with Japanese text and red logo
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Hold the sealed packet in your free hand near the sofa leg but keep a palm-width gap. While the leg surges forward, push the packet’s uneven face into your opposite palm, squeeze gently, then flick the packet edge across the skin and pull it clear.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Crinkly, air-filled snack bag can replicate the slight vibration/feedback of slicing slime without strong resistance. Still cannot compensate for the sofa leg’s mass and lack of agile movement.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the controller convex underside up on the floor 10 cm past the sofa leg’s travel line. During each thrust, press your free palm onto the shell, roll so the thumbsticks and triggers poke sequentially, then remove your hand before the leg nears.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Rolling over protruding controls gives sporadic bumps—somewhat like small vibration pulses—but still involves noticeable mechanical elements and mismatched effort from moving the sofa leg.

realism.physicalContactObject: blue fabric two-seater sofa/loveseat with black metal frame
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Kneel beside the sofa, clasp one of the front metal legs with both hands, and drive it forward in a thrusting action.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Position the bean bag on the floor so its nearest edge sits 12 cm ahead of the sofa leg’s endpoint. As you thrust, sink your free hand wrist-deep into the beads, push forward, then withdraw swiftly while the leg stops short of the cushion.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: use the lightsaber to cut slime. there should be NO resistance-based haptic feedback since the lightsaber blade is pure energy/light, requiring two physical proxies should avoid contact.
realism.explanation: Submerging into loose beads yields a yielding, fluid-like feel close to cutting through slime with minimal resistance. The sofa-leg heft again keeps the maximum realism limited.
